Hail!  ever awful maid,</br>In russet vest array'd!</br>Queen of the distant plain and rural cot!</br>Within thy peaceful cells</br>Eternal pleasure dwells,</br>And heav'n-born virtue seeks thy lonely grot.

Oft when the chearful dawn</br>Spreads o'er the bright'ning lawn,</br>With dewy hand thou call'st the op'ning flow'rs;</br>And when the genial ray,</br>Glares on the face of day,</br>Retir'st to cooling shades and fragrant bow'rs.

The soul-inspiring muse</br>Thy silent step pursues,</br>With thee she often strikes the trembling string.</br>Thou give'st the words that glow,</br>Thou give'st the verse to flow,</br>And bidst wild fancy stretch her varying wing.

Remote from noise and strife,</br>And all the cares of life,</br>With thee reflection ever deigns to dwell;</br>No rude impetuous noise</br>Disturb thy sober joys,</br>But awful silence hovers o'er thy cell.

If midst the lonely shade</br>Thou rov'st with silent tread,</br>Where gentle linnets tune the pensive lay,</br>Or on the mountain's brow,</br>Amidst the falling dew,</br>Mark'st the last gleam of evening's parting ray:

Or if thou deign'st to rove</br>Amid the moss-grown grove,</br>Or where yon cloyster's mould'ring walls extend,</br>Or on the briny steep,</br>Explor'st the caverns deep,</br>Still shall thy vot'ry on thy steps attend.</br>
